poem:
### Morning Paper

In Handsworth's heart, shadows stir,  
Robert speaks of slums, his words  
a morning chill. But I see warmth—  
faithful flickers, community hands  
igniting hope. A garden grows  
from concrete cracks; voices rise  
not as echoes of despair,  
but whispers of resilience, woven  
in the quiet tenacity of dawn.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The irony of Robert Jenrick’s ‘white face’ remarks about Handsworth | Letters On Tuesday morning I woke up and saw news about my neighbourhood. I was hoping it would be positive – about our brilliant community organisations, our fantastic faith groups, our valiant voluntary associations. However, the news was that the shadow justice secretary, Robert Jenrick, had said that my neighbourhood was “as close as I’ve come to a slum in this country” and that". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
